content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="ISO-8859-1"?>  <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3 http://www.loc.gov/standards/mods/v3/mods-3-4.xsd">    <titleInfo>       <title>Equivariant Gromov-Witten Theory of GKM Orbifolds</title>    </titleInfo>    <name type="personal" ID="Zhengyu">       <namePart type="family">Zong</namePart>       <namePart type="given">Zhengyu</namePart>       <role>          <roleTerm type="text">author</roleTerm>       </role>       <affiliation>Columbia University. Mathematics</affiliation>    </name>    <name type="personal" ID="ccliu">       <namePart type="family">Liu</namePart>       <namePart type="given">Chiu-Chu M.</namePart>       <role>          <roleTerm type="text">thesis advisor</roleTerm>       </role>       <affiliation>Columbia University. Mathematics</affiliation>    </name>    <name type="corporate">       <namePart>Columbia University. Mathematics</namePart>       <role>          <roleTerm type="text">originator</roleTerm>       </role>    </name>    <typeOfResource>text</typeOfResource>    <genre>Dissertations</genre>    <originInfo>       <dateIssued keyDate="yes">2015</dateIssued>    </originInfo>    <language>       <languageTerm type="text">English</languageTerm>    </language>    <abstract>      In this paper, we study the all genus Gromov-Witten theory for any GKM orbifold X. We generalize the Givental formula which is studied in the smooth case in [41] [42] [43] to the orbifold case. Specifically, we recover the higher genus Gromov-Witten invariants of a GKM orbifold X by its genus zero data. When X is toric, the genus zero Gromov-Witten invariants of X can be explicitly computed by the mirror theorem studied in [22] and our main theorem gives a closed formula for the all genus Gromov-Witten invariants of X. When X is a toric Calabi-Yau 3-orbifold, our formula leads to a proof of the remodeling conjecture in [38]. The remodeling conjecture can be viewed as an all genus mirror symmetry for toric Calabi-Yau 3-orbifolds. In this case, we apply our formula to the A-model higher genus potential and prove the remodeling conjecture by matching it to the B-model higher genus potential.     </abstract>    <note>Ph.D., Columbia University.</note>    <subject>       <topic>Mathematics</topic>    </subject>    <identifier type="CDRS doi">http://dx.doi.org/10.7916/D8513WZC</identifier>    <accessCondition type="restriction on access">       <extension xmlns:rioxxterms="http://docs.rioxx.net/schema/v2.0/rioxxterms/" xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3" xsi:schemaLocation="http://docs.rioxx.net/schema/v2.0/rioxxterms/ http://docs.rioxx.net/schema/v2.0/rioxxterms.xsd">          <free_to_read start_date="2014-12-01"/>       </extension>    </accessCondition>    <location>       <physicalLocation authority="marcorg">NNC</physicalLocation>    </location>    <recordInfo>       <recordContentSource authority="marcorg">NNC</recordContentSource>       <recordCreationDate>2014-12-04 09:40:48 -0500</recordCreationDate>       <recordChangeDate>2014-12-23 14:40:36 -0500</recordChangeDate>       <recordIdentifier>18773</recordIdentifier>       <languageOfCataloging>          <languageTerm authority="iso639-2b">eng</languageTerm>       </languageOfCataloging>    </recordInfo> </mods>
